comments.commentBody: It seems the College Board is trying model itself after the International Baccalaureate program, which has been using a philosophy similar to that stated above for years -- successfully, and worldwide, I might add. It's a shame more schools don't offer IB as an option. My daughter earned an IB diploma. Taking the rigorous two-year college preparatory program not only opened many doors, earned her credit hours, and helped her win numerous scholarships, but also smoothed her transition from high school to the demands of college. We have attended our district's IB awards ceremony for seven years now, and returning alumni always report how much better prepared they were for college life, stating IB taught them time management and critical thinking skills, and that they have fared better in the transition than their friends who only took AP classes.

I teach science in a small rural school. Opportunities for enrichment are challenging. When my youngest son was a junior he started taking on-line college classes from the local community college. The classes were free. There was no placement exam. The classes were taught by college teachers. He ended up as a senior with 32 quarter units which he transferred to the University where he is currently enrolled. He was admitted with sophomore standing to an engineering honors program where he continues to excel.

Such a senario requires a strong academic foundation and strong support from the high school staff and family. We currently have about 10% of our students enrolled in college classes including philosophy, nutrition and freshman composition. Most will be successful.

Re #16: "The poor do not burn dung because carbon taxes have made propane too expensive. They burn dung because it is free..."

Amusing thought, at least to a cynic like me: In the world's poorer areas (or at least poor in the eyes of those who consider western popular culture to be wealthy), people collect dung*, or wood or charcoal, to cook on because it's free.

In western society, the prosperous instead buy their charcoal in bags, pile it in expensive cookers in their suburban back yards or urban balconies, douse it with sizeable quantities of hydrocarbons, use a special tool to set it on fire, let it burn down for some time (thus wasting most of the fuel value), perhaps add chips of some exotic wood likewise bagged & purchased at some expense, and finally use the embers to cook an evening meal, perhaps inviting friends to partake of products of this quasi-religious ritual. The more devout followers of this art even hold great festivals at which they compete for prizes.

So could someone please explain again how cooking over open fires demonstrates that the people of the undeveloped world are suffering?

*I must confess that - having a plentiful supply readily to hand - I've occasionally pondered ways of turning horse manure and stable straw into some useful biofuel.

Issues of sudden starvation are far more likely than harm from AGW, this because AGW (even if you accept the speculation) is a slow process. Also, as anyone involved with agriculture will tell you, cold and wet (or even cold and arid) are far more dangerous than the alternatives to yields and production, as well as storage and transportation.

Moreover, the rising cost of food is in large measure due to inflation, caused by the world-wide monetizing of debt than anything traceable to having been caused by current carbon counts, there, no evidence exists to support an agricultural effect - in fact, more carbon supports far more plant growth than less carbon at any modern-level.

Instant starvation can happen with just one lost year of local or world agriculture, such as a highly volcanic year, or merely years along the cool-phases of multi-decadal oscillations, especially when the solar energy supporting plants is lower than the norm. There is every reason to feel this situation may be upon us in the very near future, much more quickly, suddenly and hungrily than anything remotely connected to warming.

Is there an expert on the planet with appropriate expertise who will kindly respond to two questions regarding human population dynamics.

I. Based upon the best available scientific research, is the population dynamics of the human species essentially similar to, or different from, the population dynamics of other species?

II. Is the size of the human population on Earth dependent upon, or independent of, the supply of food for human consumption? To put this second question another way, If we objectively examine the relationship between global human population numbers and the total supply of food for human consumption, are absolute global human population numbers the dependent variable or the independent variable?

Responses to the two questions above from Professor Emeritus Gary L. Peters

Hi Steve,

Some people will never comprehend what humans are doing to our planet and I don't know how to convince them otherwise......As for your two questions, I'll try briefly to answer them.

1. In his introduction to the 150th anniversary edition of Darwin's The Origin of Species, Sir Julian Huxley wrote that "As regards man, it became ever clearer that he had originated from an ancestor sufficiently ape-like to be placed in the same group with the existing great apes. Man could no longer be regarded as the Lord of Creation, a being apart from the rest of nature. He was merely the representative of one among many Families of the order Primates in the class Mammalia."

2. The second question if far more complicated. Like all other animals, human numbers cannot grow beyond the supply of food available to them. However, unlike all other animals, humans have the capacity to increase food supplies to feed growing populations. Historically there has been a two-way relationship between our numbers and food supplies. When food was abundant, human numbers grew; when food was scarce, human numbers decreased. Since population growth threatened decreases in living standards for early populations, such growth often stimulated innovation, leading us into the Neolithic and the beginning of agriculture. Subsequently, we have tended to find ways to use ever more energy to increase food supplies, starting with the use of domesticated animals to help improve agricultural production, then to irrigation projects, etc. When we succeeded populations grew; when we failed, they stagnated or declined. Populations rose and fell historically as famines, diseases, wars, and mortality staked their claims. These cyclical fluctuations were with our species until only recently, when humans began to tap into nonanimate sources of energy, especially coal, then oil, and finally natural gas. Coupled with scientific progress in agriculture, transportation, etc., humans were able to corral the four horsemen and create a surge in population growth that continues today. So long as we are able to keep producing more food, we will be able to sustain further population growth. However, there will be limits. One of them may be the peaking of oil production, which, if it hasn't already occurred, will almost certainly occur within the next few years. After that, further food production may be constrained by rising energy prices.

I don't know how many more people we might be able to feed, but I don't know why we want to maximize the number of people on the planet. Human population growth cannot continue without taking an ever heavier toll on the environment that gives us life and on the creatures with which we share the planet.

Cheers,

Gary
